questions.text: Which of the following is true about MAURICE theory?

options.label: B
options.text: Scattered light is destroyed by mutual interference

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of transparency results if lattice arrangement is altered.

questions.explanation: Ans. D) All the above

questions.text: Staphylococcus is associated with all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VKC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction and is not associated with Staphylococcus infections.

questions.text: Cornea reached adult size at.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cornea reaches its adult size (approximately 11.5 mm in horizontal diameter) by the age of 2.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Comparison between child and adult:
  • ➤ Comparison between child and adult:

questions.text: The SAFE strategy given by WHO forms the mainstream of the management of Trachoma. What does the F in the acronym represent?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Facial Cleanliness

questions.text: A child presents with proptosis, pain and Loss of vision. O/E the following picture is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Orbital cellulitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of proptosis, pain, and vision loss in a child suggests orbital cellulitis , a serious condition that requires immediate medical intervention.
  • ➤ orbital cellulitis
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: Identify what image B depicts

options.label: D
options.text: Rabbit getting ready for valentines day

questions.explanation: Ans. A) Fusion

questions.text: In concomitant squint:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Primary deviation = Secondary deviation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In concomitant squint, the primary deviation equals the secondary deviation , as the angle of deviation remains consistent in all gaze directions.
  • ➤ primary deviation equals the secondary deviation

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient, Mr. Apurv Tripathi, presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of double vision (diplopia) and difficulty moving his left eye. Upon examination, you observe that the patient has a restricted range of motion in the affected eye, particularly when attempting to look upward and outward. The patient denies any recent trauma or systemic illness. Given the clinical presentation, you suspect a possible issue with one of the extraocular muscles. Which of the following is NOT an extraocular muscle of the eye?
questions.explanation: Ans. D)

questions.text: Mydriasis is present in all the following except::
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pontine haemorrhage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pontine hemorrhage causes miosis (pupil constriction), while conditions that reduce parasympathetic activity or enhance sympathetic tone, such as third nerve lesions and Datura poisoning, cause mydriasis (pupil dilation)
  • ➤ Pontine hemorrhage causes miosis

questions.text: Optic nerve axon emerges from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ganglion cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The optic nerve is formed from axons of ganglion cells in the retina, and ganglion cell death is a primary feature of glaucoma, leading to progressive optic nerve damage.
  • ➤ optic nerve is formed from axons of ganglion cells

questions.text: All are seen in 3rd nerve palsy except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Miosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Miosis is not a feature of third nerve palsy . Instead, mydriasis (pupil dilation) is typically seen due to the loss of parasympathetic input to the pupil.
  • ➤ Miosis is not a feature of third nerve palsy

questions.text: A recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis occurring with the onset of hot weather in young boys with symptoms of burning, itching, and lacrimation with large, flat- topped cobblestone papillae, raised areas in the palpebral conjunctiva is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a recurrent, bilateral conjunctivitis affecting young boys in hot weather, characterized by cobblestone papillae, itching, burning, and lacrimation, and managed with antihistamines, mast cell stabilizers, and topical steroids.

questions.text: A patient Mr Anand Garg of old standing diabetes mellitus noticed sudden muscae volitanes. On examination, the red reflex was dim, with no details of fundus could be seen. He might have:
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy

questions.text: Number of layers in neurosensory retina is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 9

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The neurosensory retina has 9 layers , while the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) forms the 10th layer, completing the retina’s structure.
  • ➤ neurosensory retina has 9 layers
  • ➤ retinal pigment epithelium (RPE)

questions.text: Volume of posterior segment is.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4 ml

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The volume of the posterior segment of the eye is 4 ml.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Orbital volume: 30 mL
  • ➤ Globe volume: 6.5 mL
  • ➤ Anterior chamber volume: 250 μL
  • ➤ Aqueous humor forms: 2–2.5 μL/min
  • ➤ Conjunctival sac volume: 35 μL
  • ➤ Conjunctival sac volume: 35 μL
  • ➤ Eyedrop volume: 50 μL
  • ➤ Eyedrop volume: 50 μL
  • ➤ Corneal thickness: 500–600 μm
  • ➤ Corneal thickness: 500–600 μm
  • ➤ K horizontal diameter (infant): 10 mm
  • ➤ K horizontal diameter (infant): 10 mm
  • ➤ K horizontal diameter (adult): 11.5 mm
  • ➤ K horizontal diameter (adult): 11.5 mm
  • ➤ Lens diameter: 9.5 mm
  • ➤ Anterior capsule thickness 14 μm
  • ➤ Posterior capsule thickness 2–4 μm
  • ➤ Rod photoreceptor cells: 120 million
  • ➤ Rod photoreceptor cells: 120 million
  • ➤ Cone photoreceptor cells: 6 million
  • ➤ Cone photoreceptor cells: 6 million
  • ➤ Retinal ganglion cells (at birth): 1.2 million
  • ➤ Retinal ganglion cells (at birth): 1.2 million
  • ➤ 52% of optic nerve fibers cross in optic chiasm (nasal fibers)
  • ➤ 52% of optic nerve fibers cross in optic chiasm (nasal fibers)

questions.text: Retro-bulbar optic neuritis is characterized by:

options.label: A
options.text: Marked swelling of the optic disc.

options.label: B
options.text: Impaired direct light reflex in the affected eye

options.label: C
options.text: Impaired consensual light reflex in the affected eye

questions.correct_answer: B. Impaired direct light reflex in the affected eye
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Impaired direct light reflex in the affected eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retro-bulbar optic neuritis is characterized by impaired direct light reflex due to damage to the afferent pathway, with a normal-looking optic disc despite significant vision loss.
  • ➤ impaired direct light reflex

questions.text: One of the earliest features of anterior uveitis includes:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Aqueous flare

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aqueous flare is the earliest feature of anterior uveitis , indicating inflammation and protein leakage in the anterior chamber. Other findings such as keratic precipitates, hypopyon, and posterior synechiae occur later as the inflammation progresses.
  • ➤ Aqueous flare
  • ➤ earliest feature of anterior uveitis

questions.text: The most important symptom differentiating orbital cellulitis from panophthalmitis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most important symptom differentiating orbital cellulitis from panophthalmitis is the presence of vision loss, which is invariably seen in panophthalmitis due to retinal involvement.

questions.text: Ciliary injection is not seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Catarrhal conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ciliary injection (circumciliary congestion) is typically seen in conditions involving the deeper ocular structures, such as the cornea and iris, and is not present in conjunctival diseases like catarrhal conjunctivitis.

questions.text: Severe congenital ptosis with no levator function can be treated by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fascia lata sling operation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fascia lata sling surgery is the treatment of choice for severe congenital ptosis with no levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) function, allowing the frontalis muscle to compensate for eyelid elevation.

questions.text: Chalazion is a chronic inflammatory granuloma of
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Meibomian gland

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chalazion is a chronic inflammatory granuloma of the Meibomian gland, presenting as a painless swelling away from the lid margin.

questions.text: The effective treatment of dendritic ulcer of the cornea is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acyclovir ointment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The effective treatment for dendritic ulcers caused by Herpes Simplex Virus is topical antiviral therapy, specifically acyclovir ointment, which targets the viral replication and promotes healing .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: Fifth nerve palsy could cause:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neuropathic keratopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fifth nerve palsy can cause neuropathic keratopathy due to loss of corneal sensation, leading to impaired blink reflex and corneal damage.

questions.text: In trachoma the patient is infectious when there is:

options.label: D
options.text: Follicles and papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva.

questions.correct_answer: D. Follicles and papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Follicles and papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In trachoma, the infectious stage is identified by the presence of follicles and papillae in the palpebral conjunctiva, which indicate active inflammation and transmissibility .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A patient complains of maceration of skin of the lids and conjunctiva redness at the inner and outer canthi. Conjunctival swab is expected to show:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Moraxella- Axenfeld diplobacilli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diplobacillary (angular) conjunctivitis, characterized by maceration at the inner and outer canthi, is caused by Moraxella-Axenfeld diplobacilli and is effectively treated with zinc oxide and antibiotic ointments .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A young child suffering from fever and sore throat began to complain of lacrimation. On examination, follicles were found in the lower palpebral conjunctiva with tender preauricular lymph nodes. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenoviral conjunctivitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pharyngoconjunctival fever, caused by adenovirus, presents with fever, sore throat, follicular conjunctivitis, and tender preauricular lymph nodes, making adenoviral conjunctivitis the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: Primary optic atrophy results from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Neurological disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary optic atrophy results from neurological diseases affecting the optic nerve directly, without preceding optic disc swelling or inflammation.
  • ➤ Primary optic atrophy results from neurological diseases

questions.text: Extraocular muscles originate from:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mesoderm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Extraocular muscles derive from the mesoderm, while other eye structures originate from different embryonic layers such as neuroectoderm, neural crest, and surface ectoderm.
  • ➤ Note :
  • ➤ Note

questions.text: The 68-year-old female patient has had a diabetic cataract for 3 months. Accumulation of which of the following substances is responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sorbitol + Fructose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The accumulation of sorbitol and fructose within the lens due to high blood sugar levels in diabetics leads to diabetic cataract formation, particularly characterized by snowflake opacities .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: The nerve placed outside the muscle cone is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IV Nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The trochlear nerve (IV) is the only cranial nerve that supplies an extraocular muscle (superior oblique) from outside the muscle cone formed by the rectus muscles .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Muscle Cone: Formed by the four rectus muscles originating from the annulus of Zinn, surrounding the optic nerve and ciliary ganglion in the orbit. Ciliary Ganglion Location: Located within the muscle cone, 5–20 mm posterior to the globe on the lateral aspect of the optic nerve.
  • ➤ Muscle Cone: Formed by the four rectus muscles originating from the annulus of Zinn, surrounding the optic nerve and ciliary ganglion in the orbit.
  • ➤ Muscle Cone:
  • ➤ Ciliary Ganglion Location: Located within the muscle cone, 5–20 mm posterior to the globe on the lateral aspect of the optic nerve.
  • ➤ Ciliary Ganglion Location:

questions.text: The best treatment for amblyopia is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Occlusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Occlusion therapy (patching of the good eye) is the most effective treatment for amblyopia in young children, forcing the amblyopic eye to improve through increased usage. Penalization with atropine drops can also be used if patching is not tolerated.

questions.text: The action of inferior oblique is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Elevation, extorsion, abduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The inferior oblique muscle causes elevation, extorsion, and abduction of the eye. It is also the only extraocular muscle that does not originate from the orbital apex; instead, it arises from the medial wall of the orbit.
  • ➤ inferior oblique muscle
  • ➤ elevation, extorsion, and abduction
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:

questions.text: D-shaped pupil occurs in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Iridodialysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A D-shaped pupil is characteristic of iridodialysis , caused by detachment of the iris due to blunt trauma. This condition may be accompanied by monocular diplopia, rosette cataract, hyphema, commotio retinae, and other trauma-related ocular findings.
  • ➤ D-shaped pupil
  • ➤ iridodialysis

questions.text: Papilloedema has all the following characteristics except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Marked loss of vision

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Papilloedema is characterized by blurring of the disc margins, hyperemia, and enlargement of the physiological blind spot as the primary field defect. Marked loss of vision is not an early feature.
  • ➤ blurring of the disc margins, hyperemia, and enlargement of the physiological blind spot
  • ➤ Marked loss of vision is not an early feature.

questions.text: Optic nerve function is best studied by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Perimetry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The function of the optic nerve is best assessed using perimetry , which detects visual field defects indicative of optic nerve damage.
  • ➤ function of the optic nerve
  • ➤ perimetry

questions.text: Unilateral aphakia is likely to be corrected by any of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Glasses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For unilateral aphakia , glasses are the least preferred correction method due to significant image magnification, distortion, and binocular vision issues . The posterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL) is the best choice, followed by contact lenses when IOL implantation is not feasible.
  • ➤ unilateral aphakia
  • ➤ image magnification, distortion, and binocular vision issues
  • ➤ posterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL)

questions.text: The most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Choroidal melanoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults is choroidal melanoma , whereas in children, it is retinoblastoma .
  • ➤ most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults
  • ➤ choroidal melanoma
  • ➤ retinoblastoma
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ The most common primary intraorbital malignancy in adults is cavernous hemangioma . The most common primary intraorbital malignancy in children is rhabdomyosarcoma . The most common malignancy of the eyelids is basal cell carcinoma (BCC) .
  • ➤ The most common primary intraorbital malignancy in adults is cavernous hemangioma .
  • ➤ intraorbital malignancy in adults
  • ➤ cavernous hemangioma
  • ➤ The most common primary intraorbital malignancy in children is rhabdomyosarcoma .
  • ➤ intraorbital malignancy in children
  • ➤ rhabdomyosarcoma
  • ➤ The most common malignancy of the eyelids is basal cell carcinoma (BCC) .
  • ➤ eyelids
  • ➤ basal cell carcinoma (BCC)

questions.text: Commonest lesion which hinders vision in diabetic retinopathy is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Macular oedema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The commonest lesion causing vision loss in diabetic retinopathy is macular oedema , specifically Clinically Significant Macular Edema (CSME) , which can occur at any stage of diabetic retinopathy.
  • ➤ commonest lesion causing vision loss in diabetic retinopathy
  • ➤ macular oedema
  • ➤ Clinically Significant Macular Edema (CSME)

questions.text: Neovascular glaucoma follows:
questions.correct_answer: A. Thrombosis of central retinal vein
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thrombosis of central retinal vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neovascular glaucoma follows thrombosis of the central retinal vein (CRVO) due to neovascularization caused by ischemia and VEGF stimulation. The initial treatment involves anti-VEGF therapy, followed by definitive treatment with panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) to shrink the abnormal vessels.
  • ➤ Neovascular glaucoma
  • ➤ thrombosis of the central retinal vein (CRVO)
  • ➤ anti-VEGF
  • ➤ panretinal photocoagulation (PRP)

questions.text: Proptosis is present in the following condition except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Horner's syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proptosis is not associated with Horner's syndrome; instead, it presents with apparent enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis.

questions.text: Evisceration is:

options.label: B
options.text: Excision of all the inner contents of the eyeball including the uveal tissue

questions.correct_answer: B. Excision of all the inner contents of the eyeball including the uveal tissue
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Excision of all the inner contents of the eyeball including the uveal tissue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Evisceration involves removing the inner contents of the eyeball, including uveal tissue, while preserving the scleral shell.

questions.text: 3 months old infant with watering lacrimal sac on pressing causes regurgitation of mucopus material. What is the appropriate treatment?

options.label: D
options.text: Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months

questions.correct_answer: D. Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Massage with antibiotics up to age of 6 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In infants under six months with nasolacrimal duct obstruction, the recommended initial treatment is Crigler massage with topical antibiotics. Probing is generally reserved for cases that do not resolve by six months of age.

questions.text: Ptosis in Horner's syndrome, is due to paralysis of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Muller's muscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ptosis in Horner's syndrome is due to paralysis of Muller's muscle, which is innervated by the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: Advanced keratoconus is least to be corrected when treated by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Spectacles.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spectacles are not effective for vision correction in advanced keratoconus; other options like RGP lenses or keratoplasty are preferred for better visual outcomes.

questions.text: Topical steroids are contraindicated in a case of viral corneal ulcer for fear of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Corneal perforation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Topical steroids are contraindicated in cases of viral corneal ulcers due to the risk of corneal perforation, which can lead to severe complications, including loss of vision.

questions.text: A female patient 18 years old, who is contact lens wearer since two years, is complaining of redness, lacrimation and foreign body sensation of both eyes. On examination, visual acuity was 6/6 with negative fluorescein test. The expected diagnosis can be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Giant papillary conjunctivitis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant papillary conjunctivitis is a common allergic reaction in contact lens wearers, presenting with redness, lacrimation, and foreign body sensation. It is not associated with corneal epithelial defects, hence a negative fluorescein test.

questions.text: Muscle inserted farthest from limbus is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) SR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superior rectus (SR) muscle is inserted farthest from the limbus, approximately 7.7 mm away, following the pattern described by the spiral of Tillaux.

questions.text: A 12 years old boy receiving long term treatment for spring catarrh, developed defective vision in both eyes. The likely cause is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior subcapsular cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-term steroid use, commonly prescribed for conditions like spring catarrh, can lead to the development of posterior subcapsular cataract , a toxic cataract that significantly affects vision.
  • ➤ posterior subcapsular cataract

questions.text: Irrespective of the etiology of a corneal ulcer, the drug always indicated is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cycloplegics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cycloplegics, such as atropine, are always indicated in corneal ulcers to reduce pain from ciliary spasm and prevent complications like posterior synechiae, regardless of the ulcer’s etiology.

questions.text: Paton's line is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Papilledema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paton’s lines, circumferential retinal folds around the optic disc, are a classic sign of papilledema , indicating raised intracranial pressure.
  • ➤ papilledema

questions.text: Presbyopia is due to
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presbyopia results from a combination of loss of lens elasticity , weakness of ciliary muscles , and weakness of suspensory ligaments , all contributing to the eye's diminished ability to focus on near objects.
  • ➤ loss of lens elasticity
  • ➤ weakness of ciliary muscles
  • ➤ weakness of suspensory ligaments

questions.text: Occlusion of the lower nasal branch of the central retinal artery results in one of the following field defects:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Upper temporal field defect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An occlusion in the lower nasal branch of the central retinal artery causes a defect in the upper temporal visual field due to the inverted and reversed projection of the retina on the visual field.
  • ➤ defect in the upper temporal visual field

questions.text: Topical atropine is contraindicated in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Primary angle closure glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Topical atropine is contraindicated in primary angle closure glaucoma due to the risk of exacerbating angle closure and raising intraocular pressure.
  • ➤ primary angle closure glaucoma

questions.text: Which laser is used for capsulotomy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) ND: YAG laser

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Nd:laser is the preferred laser for performing capsulotomy to treat posterior capsule opacification, allowing non-invasive restoration of vision after cataract surgery.
  • ➤ Nd:laser
  • ➤ Note :
  • ➤ Note
  • ➤ Common used lasers
  • ➤ Common used lasers

questions.text: Lagophthalmos can occur in all of the following except.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5thcranial nerve paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lagophthalmos is not caused by 5th cranial nerve (trigeminal nerve) paralysis , as it is primarily related to facial nerve (7th cranial nerve) dysfunction or mechanical restrictions.
  • ➤ 5th cranial nerve (trigeminal nerve) paralysis

questions.text: In DCR, the opening is made at:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Middle meatus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the new drainage opening is made in the middle meatus to bypass a blocked nasolacrimal duct.
  • ➤ middle meatus

questions.text: A 35-year-old male Mr Praveen Gupta presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of difficulty seeing at night, which has progressively worsened over the past six months. He describes experiencing significant challenges while driving in low light conditions and finds it difficult to adapt to sudden changes in lighting, such as entering a dark room from a brightly lit area. The patient denies any other visual disturbances during the day. He does not wear glasses and has no significant past medical history. On Examination: ⁠ Visual acuity: 20/20 in both eyes. ⁠ Pupillary reaction: Normal. Fundoscopic examination: black pigment deposits, thinning of retinal vessels and optic nerve head pallor. ⁠ Conjunctiva: No pallor or jaundice noted. ⁠ Extraocular movements: Full range of motion without pain or restriction. Laboratory Tests: ⁠ Complete blood count (CBC): Within normal limits. ⁠ Serum vitamin levels: Vitamin A level is notably low. Based on the patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and laboratory results, what is the most likely cause of his night blindness?
questions.explanation: Ans. B)

questions.text: A one-month old baby is brought with complaints of intolerance to bright light and watering. Clinical examination shows normal tear passages and clear but large cornea. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Buphthalmos

questions.text: 62 years old Mrs. Bajaj presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe pain in her right eye, blurred vision, and a headache and nausea . In systemic history she had Hypertension, and Type 2 Diabetes In family history Father had glaucoma On examination, her right eye is red, the pupil is mid-dilated and non-reactive to light, and the cornea is cloudy. Her intraocular pressure (IOP) in the right eye is significantly elevated at 50 mmHg. After receiving initial medical treatment to lower her IOP, the ophthalmologist discusses the management plan. What is the recommended treatment for the left (fellow) eye to prevent a similar occurrence?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Yag Laser iridotomy

questions.text: A value of 0.75 D was deduced from the retinoscopy reading as a part of drug correction. The likely drug used was?
questions.explanation: Ans. C)

questions.text: Schirmer’s test is used for diagnosing:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Dry eye

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic with a complaint of gradually worsening vision in her right eye over the past year. She reports no pain but mentions a history of a severe eye infection in the same eye about three years ago. On examination, the right eye shows a whitish, opaque lesion on the cornea, with vascularization extending into the cornea from the limbus. The lesion appears to be adhered to the underlying structures. Slit-lamp examination confirms the presence of a dense, adherent corneal scar with associated neovascularization. The patient's left eye is unremarkable, and her systemic review is non-contributory. What is the most appropriate diagnosis for this patient?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Adherent leucoma

questions.text: Accessory row of eyelashes is:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Distichiasis

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to your clinic seeking evaluation for Laser-Assisted in Situ Keratomileusis surgery to correct her myopia. She reports that she does not have any significant medical or ocular history. Her visual acuity is 20/400 in both eyes, which improves to 20/20 with corrective lenses. Which of the following is the most appropriate criterion that must be met before she can be considered eligible for surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: Her age should be over 30 years.

options.label: B
options.text: Her corneal thickness should be at least 540 micrometers.

options.label: C
options.text: She should not have a history of contact lens use.

options.label: D
options.text: Her refractive error should have been stable for at least one year.

questions.correct_answer: D. Her refractive error should have been stable for at least one year.
questions.explanation: Ans. D)

questions.text: A 35 year old male Anand Jain on slit lamp shows keratic precipitates & aqueous flare in his right eye. No synechiae but a complicated cataract is seen. The probable diagnosis would be:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Heterochromic iridocyclitis of Fuch’s

questions.text: A male patient 30 years old Gobind Gupta with visual acuity of 6/6 in both eyes. Twelve hours ago he presented with drop of vision of the left eye. On examination, visual acuity was 6/6 in the right eye and 6/60 in the left eye. Fundus examination showed blurred edges of the left optic disc. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Optic neuritis

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with complaints of gradual loss of peripheral vision over the past few months. On examination, intraocular pressure is found to be elevated. Visual field testing reveals characteristic defects consistent with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). Which of the following treatment options is the most appropriate initial therapy for managing this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Ans. A)

questions.text: The finding that all three types of Duane’s syndrome share is:
questions.explanation: Ans. B)

questions.text: A 68-year-old female Raina Vohra presents with gradual onset of blurred vision, glare sensitivity, and difficulty with night driving over the past year. On examination, visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral opacification of the crystalline lenses with cortical and nuclear changes. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable, with no evidence of retinal pathology. Which of the following surgical options is most commonly used for the treatment of this patient's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Intracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

options.label: C
options.text: Extracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

questions.correct_answer: A. Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation

questions.text: Identify the lesion and its etiology:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Koeppes Nodules- Uveitis

questions.text: Amongst which of the following conditions is the given instrument used?
questions.explanation: Ans. B) Dacryocystorhinostomy

questions.text: The color of fluorescein staining in corneal ulcer is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Green

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluorescein staining in corneal ulcers appears green under cobalt blue light, highlighting areas of epithelial damage.
  • ➤ green

questions.text: Identify the disease and procedure being performed?
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Keratoconus- C3R

questions.text: A male patient with a history of hyper­mature cataract presents with a 2 day history of ciliary congestion, photo­phobia, blurring of vision and on exami­nation has a deep anterior chamber in the right eye. The left eye is normal. The patient is best treated by:
questions.explanation: Ans. B)

questions.text: The commonest cause of appearance shown in the image above would be:
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Thyroid eye disease
